intro.para:
When a particle moves in space, it changes its location at each instant. This change of location is characterized by the direction and the speed of the motion at that instant. Both data combined comprise the velocity at that instant. As velocity is characterized by direction and magnitude, we may represent it by a
vector
Illustration of Vectors representing Velocities
For example, suppose a vector of length 1 corresponds to the speed of 20km/h. Then the following arrows represent velocities as indicated.
What does the red arrow mean?
This vector represents a velocity of 80km/h to the right
What does the green arrow mean?
This vector represents the velocity of \sqrt{58}\cdot 20km/h towords the upper right
What does the blue arrow mean?
This vector represent the velocity of 100km/h towards the lower left.
. The direction of the vector gives the direction of the motion and the length of the vector corresponds to the speed.

section.body.para: Experiments show that superposition of motions corresponds to addition of the corresponding velocity vectors. For example: The motion of a person on a ship relative to a point on shore is superpositioned from

li.para: The motion of the water relative to the point on shore
The motion of the ship relative to the water surrounding it
The motion of the person relative to the structure of the ship.

section.body.para: The velocity vector of the moving person relative to a point on shore is the sum of these three velocity vectors.
Similarly, the motion of an aircraft relative to the ground depends upon the wind which carries the aircraft and the superimposed motion resulting from the aircraftâ€™s own propulsion.

info.caption: What does the blue arrow mean?
info.para: This vector represents the velocity of the aircraft relative to the surrounding air.

info.caption: What does the green arrow mean?
info.para: This vector represents the velocity of the air relative to the ground.

info.caption: What does the red arrow mean?
info.para: This vector represents the velocity of the aircraft relative to the ground.
